Posts.Content: Oct 11, 2014 12:20PM - edited Oct 11, 2014 12:23PM by nursiellp Boy, do I feel your pain.  Some history here.  I had a excisional biopsy in my early 20's that was a fibroid.   Years later they found some microcalcifications.  Had stereotactic biopsy.  It was benign.  Then next mammo had more microcalcifications and a cyst.  2 more stereotactic biopsies and an U.S guided biopsy.   All benign. I got so sick of these multiple biopsies that I just stopped getting mammos.   I would joke that my surgeon. was removing my right breast millimeter at a time.  Fast forward, THE LUMP.  It was very small, the size of a pea and I mentioned it to my medical Dr. and she wrote a script for screening mammo.  I thought awww, it's probably just a cyst and let it go, again.  Now a year later I am a menopausal 51 yr old and the lump grew tremendously in the past 3 months.  I also have skin thickening and it is attached to the skin of my areola.  You can actually see it . I know, I was stupid and I'm a nurse to boot.  I should have never let it go so long and frankly, I'm sick of my friends saying that.  I got a diagnostic mammo and they kept doing more and more views.  Then they sent me in for an U.S.  radiologist came in to do it  that took forever.  Had this happen before, no biggie.  The radiologist starts talking and I not only have this lump but 2 more suspicious microcalcifications and multiple cysts.  BI-RADS 4B.  So, I go the surgeon a week ago.  That morning I found another lump just above the big one.  Mammo says it's a cyst but I totally didn't feel it before.  I bring that up to the Dr.  Now, I know this Dr. well from previous biopsies and from my being a nurse at the hospital.  I start joking with him, as we also do, I said I've been falling all over the place in the past 3 months and actually fractured my wrist and I'm limping because I just fell on the way to his office.  I say "So now I'm convinced that I not only have breast cancer, I have mets to the brain too!  lol"  He looked at me over his glasses, straight faced and said "lets just look at this first".  Hit panic button!  I am scheduled on Wed for 2 stereotactic biopsies and then they're going to turn me around to have an excisional biopsy.  Since then I found 2 swollen, painful lymph nodes under my arm.  I have been differing to Dr. Google almost every waking moment..  I can't even watch my favorite TV shows because I can't pay attention that long.  I'm surprised that I could even write for this long on the subject but it's very therapeutic.  I absolutely am convinced that I have breast CA and MAYBE mets to the brain.  So, writesthings, after that long sob story, I have to say this. If you look at my history you will notice that I've had 4 stereotactic biopsies an US guided biopsy and an excisional biopsy and they were ALL BENIGN.  After 2 more stereotactic biopsies and another excisional biopsy I will probably be saying it again.  I know that a BI-RADS 4 is good news and nothing to panic about.  The rational thing is not to panic but it's your natural reaction to your body's fight or flight response.  The good thing is that the panic will stop when you get your results and you can either drop the whole sorry mess or the fight will come out like you've never seen before!. . Praying for you all.  It's the only thing to do right now besides panicking!
Posts.Title: Biopsy on Monday, and (of course) scared writesthings Ariom

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2014 05:16AM nursiellp wrote: Thank you moderators.  I hope we're not scarring away people with our diagnosis.  lol.  I know waiting is the hardest part!
Posts.Title: Biopsy on Monday, and (of course) scared writesthings Ariom

Posts.Content: Oct 24, 2014 05:26AM nursiellp wrote: drewcella As you can see above I've had numerous biopsies, 2 excisional.  The worst part is the sutures afterward.  They poke out of everything you wear and it's a pain in the butt.  If I'm complaining about this now I can just imagine what the mastectomy will be like.  lol!  The absolute worst part is the waiting!
Posts.Title: Biopsy on Monday, and (of course) scared writesthings Ariom

Posts.Content: Oct 22, 2014 07:05AM nursiellp wrote: Hi folks.  Had my biopsies on Wednesday.  Found out I have I have invasive ductal carcinoma yesterday.  When the surgeon told me I said "I knew that" and he said "I know you knew that"  lol.  Anywho, He wants me to have a modified radical mastectomy because of my history, apparent lymph node involvement (they are now huge and ouchy!) and cosmetically because of my breast size.  I never considered my  large breast to be a problem at al!  He seems to want to do this as soon as possible because of its fast growth.  I totally concur with this and have an appointment with plastics on the 3rd to do reconstruction at the time of surgery. All that being said I have a question.  He told me that there is no need to talk to a oncologist at this point because they won't know about the lymph node involvement until after surgery.  He said that the plan of care with oncology will be totally different.  I understand this but it came as a bit of a shock.   The first thing to pop into mind was I need an oncologist stat.  Is this a normal course of care?  Did you have the same assessment?   Just asking because you women at the pros at this! Writesthings, I will be following you closely because we seem to be diagnosed with just about the same thing at the same time.  I have become your new fan and I am your new stalker! LOL.  Hope to hear from you all soon.
Posts.Title: Biopsy on Monday, and (of course) scared writesthings Ariom

Posts.Content: Nov 6, 2014 01:49AM nursiellp wrote: I am now playing the hurry up and wait game too.  The BS wanted the PS to see me faster than my appointment 2 weeks away.  That was a no go.  When I go to the PS he tells me that the surgery will be done next week or the following week at the latest.  I know people who had to wait months and I was ecstatic.  Then the office calls me yesterday and tells me Dec. 10th.  URRGH!
